data.title: Jeremy Turcotte, Trained Journalist
data.meta_description: He can also do other things
data.text:
Canada’s earliest diplomatic relations were all conducted through the British imperial diplomatic system. Canada opened an office of the Department of Immigration in Hong Kong in 1923, coinciding with the passage of Canada’s Chinese Immigration Act, severely limiting the number of Chinese persons who could immigrate to Canada. As one of the few classes of Chinese people exempt from exclusion were merchants, trade between China and Canada continued apace, and a Trade Commission office was opened in Kong Kong in 1927.

Following the Japanese invasion of French Indochina in July 1941, Canada suspended friendly relations with Japan, and began to seek closer relations with China as an ally in case of war. Canada got in contact with the Nationalist Chinese government under Gen. Chiang Kai-shek, and an exchange of diplomatic missions was agreed to August 1941. The establishment of these missions suffered delay: the Chinese envoy, Dr. Liu Shih-Shun, arrived in Ottawa in February 1942, and the Canadian envoy, Maj.-Gen. Victor Odlum, was appointed that November, but it was not until April 1943 that Odlum arrived in China opening the Canadian mission at the Chinese temporary wartime capital at Chongqing (Chungking). In November 1943, Canada and China agreed to elevate each other’s envoys to the rank of Ambassadors; Dr. Liu presented his credentials to the Governor-General of Canada in February 1944, and Maj.-Gen. Odlum did the same to Gen. Chiang in March. Once the war was over, the embassy moved to the permanent Nationalist capital of Nanjing (Nanking) in 1946. The Chinese Immigration Act was then repealed in 1947.

Communist troops took control of Nanjing in April of 1949. The Canadian ambassador was replaced by a chargé d’affaires that July, but Canada recognized the Communist government of the People’s Republic of China. Negotiations to re-establish representation at the level of Ambassador were cut off by the outbreak of the Korean War, however, and the Canadian Embassy in Nanjing was closed in February 1951. Canada continued to recognize the Nationalist government of the Republic of China, but did not send diplomatic representation to its new capital at Taipei; instead, all relations were maintained through the ROC’s embassy in Ottawa, at 301 Wurtemburg St. (The addresses of Wurtemburg St. have since been reassigned; the site is now a private home at #223.)

Canada recognized the People’s Republic of China as the sole legitimate government of China in October 1970, and, after the appointment of a new Canadian Ambassador in April, a Canadian Embassy was opened in Beijing in June 1971, at 19 Dongzhimenwai Dajie, Chaoyang District, Beijing. The new Chinese embassy was opened in Ottawa in 1972 at 515 St. Patrick St., in a former convent of the Sisters of Good Shepherd. Canada also maintains consulates at Chongqing, Guangzhou (Canton), Shanghai and Hong Kong. There is also the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei, which is Canada’s de facto embassy in Taiwan; it was originally opened by the Canadian Chamber of Commerce in 1986, but its operation was taken over by the Canadian government in 1991.

The Trade Commissioner at Hong Kong was also assigned the office of Consul-General to Macao in 1980; after the return of Hong Kong to China in 1997, the trade commission there was upgraded to a consulate, but the Consul-General to Kong Kong and Macao, owing to the special administrative status of those two cities in China, reports directly to the Department of Global Affairs in Ottawa, rather than to the Ambassador to China.

The Canadian Ambassador to China has also been concurrently the Ambassador to Vietnam from 1973 to 1979, the Ambasador to Mongolia from 1992 to 2008, and the Ambassador to North Korea from 2001 to 2005.

Canada’s representatives to China have been:

Maj.-Gen. Victor Wentworth Odlum CB CMG DSO (1880-1971), 1942-1946. Born in Coburg, Ont., Odlum’s father, the historian Edward Odlum, moved the family to Japan for four years when Victor was a child, returning to Canada in 1890 and settling in Vancouver. Odlum served in the Boer War with the Royal Canadian Regiment and, on his return, found a job as a reporter with the Vancouver Daily World, working his way up to editor-in-chief of the newspaper by the age of 25. He signed up for the Army at the outbreak of World War I and commissioned as a major, seeing action at the Second Battle of Ypres, and becoming known in the trenches as “Pea-Soup Odlum” for his teetotaling. The commanding general of the Canadian Forces, Sir Arthur Currie, took a shining to Odlum, especially as Odlum loaned Currie a large sum of money to cover some cash he “borrowed” from regimental funds before the war, thus avoiding a court-martial for embezzlement. By the end of the war, Odlum was a brigadier-general. He retired to private life in Vancouver, starting up an investment firm (Odlum Brown, which still operates to this day) and serving in the provincial legislature as a Liberal from 1924 to 1928. He also bought the Vancouver Daily Star and used it as a mouthpiece for his reactionary pro-temperance, anti-Bolshevik opinions, as well as using yellow journalism to stir up anti-Chinese sentiments in 1924 by baselessly insinuating a Chinese houseboy had murdered a Scottish housemaid in the household of a well-to-do family. Odlum shut down the Star in 1932 after the employees unionized and refused to accept a pay cut. Odlum then sat on the Board of Governors of the CBC from its founding in 1936 to the outbreak of World War II in 1939. Upon the start of the war, Odlum was commissioned as a major-general and placed in command of the 2nd Canadian Infantry Division, where he proceeded to waste time doing things like designing badges and organizing marching bands instead of arranging to train his soldiers in modern warfare tactics. Eventually Odlum was shuffled out of active military command and made High Commissioner to Australia in 1941, then Envoy to China from 1942 to 1946, upgraded in title to Ambassador to China in 1944. He then served as Canada’s first Ambassador to Turkey from 1947 to 1952. He retired to Vancouver, donating his personal library of over 100,000 volumes to the University of British Columbia in 1963.

George Sutton Patterson (acting) (Chargé d’affaires a.i.) 4-24 October 1946

The Hon. Thomas Clayton Davis (1889-1960), 1946-1949. Davis was born in Prince Albert, Sask., and studied at Osgoode Hall Law School. He was mayor of Prince Albert from 1921 to 1924 and a Liberal member of the Legislative Assembly of Saskatchewan from 1925 to 1939, in which position he convinced the federal government to found Prince Albert National Park. He was appointed to serve as a judge of the Saskatchewan Court of Appeal from 1939 to 1948, although he did not actually serve on the bench from 1940 to 1948, as he was serving as the federal Deputy Minister of War Services from 1940 to 1943, then as High Commissioner to Australia from 1943 to 1946 before becoming Ambassador to China from 1946 to 1949. He was thereafter Ambassador to West Germany from 1949 to 1954 and Ambassador to Japan from 1954 to 1957; he then retired to Victoria.

Chester Alvin Ronning CC AOE (1894-1984), 1949-1951. Chester Ronning was born to Norwegian-American Lutheran missionaries in China in the city of Fancheng, in Hubei province (since absorbed into the neighbouring city of Xiangyang [Siangyang]). Ronning moved to Canada when his father, Halvor Ronning, became involved in the establishment of an all-Norwegian settlement in northwestern Alberta, Valhalla Centre. Ronning studied at the University of Alberta and returned to China as a missionary from 1922 to 1927, returning to Alberta to become Principal of Camrose Lutheran College. Ronning also served in the legislature of Alberta from 1932 to 1935 as a member of the United Farmers of Alberta, then became leader of the Co-Operative Commonwealth Federation of Alberta in 1940. In 1942, Ronning left his positions with the College and the CCF to serve in the decryption unit of the RCAF Intelligence DIvision, then was asked to join the staff of the Canadian embassy in Chongqing in 1945. Ronning took control of the Canadian embassy at Nanjing as a chargé d’affaires from Davis’s departure in 1949 until the embassy’s closure in 1951. He then served as Ambassador to Norway from 1954 to 1957 and High Commissioner to India from 1957 to 1964. Ronning officially retired from the diplomatic service in 1965, but in 1966 he was chosen to lead Operation Smallbridge, a special mission to Hanoi by the Canadian government to bring the US and North Vietnam to the negotiating table to end the Vietnam War, which was ultimately unsuccessful.

(No representative 1951-1971)

John MacLeod Fraser (acting) (Chargé d’affaires a.i.) January-June 1971

Ralph Edgar Collins (1914-1992), 1971-1972. Ralph Collins was born in Kunming, Yunnan province, to missionary parents. He joined the diplomatic corps in 1940 and served at the Chongqing Embassy in World War II. He served as Ambassador to South Africa from 1964 to 1965, then headed negotiations with Beijing for Canada’s recognition of the Communist government before being appointed by Pierre Trudeau as Canada’s first ambassador to the People’s Republic of China, serving only about a year before a serious problem with his circulatory system forced him into an early retirement.

Charles John Small (1919-2006), 1972-1976. John Small was born to missionary parents in China, in Chengdu, Sichuan province (Chengtu, Szechwan province). He attended the Ontario Agricultural College, then served in the Navy in WWII. After the war, Small earned a degree from the University of Toronto, then joined the Department of Trade and Commerce and was posted as an agricultural commissioner to The Hague from 1950 to 1955, then was posted as a trade commissioner to Hong Kong in 1958, eventually transferring to the Department of External Affairs. He was Canada’s representative to the OECD from 1965 to 1969, then High Commissioner to Pakistan from 1969 to 1972 before becoming Ambassador to China and concurrently being named Ambassador to Vietnam in 1973, serving through the deaths of Premier Zhou Enlai (Chou En-lai) and Chairman Mao Zedong (Mao Tse-tung) and the end of the Vietnam War. He was later Deputy Secretary-General of the Commonwealth from 1979 to 1983, then served as High Commissioner to Malaysia and Brunei from 1983 to 1984.

Arthur Redpath Menzies CM (1916-2010), 1976-1980. Menzies was born to Canadian Presbyterian missionaries in Changde, Hunan province. His father, James Mellon Menzies, was a part-time archaeologist who made a study of “oracle bones”, bits of sheep bone and turtle shell etched with early examples of Chinese writing. Arthur Menzies graduated from high school in Kobe, Japan, then studied at U of T and Harvard. He joined the foreign service in 1940, soon thereafter marrying the daughter of Undersecretary for External Affairs O.D. Skelton. Menzies was in charge of the ministry’s Far Eastern department by 1945, then served as Head of Mission to the Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers in Japan from 1950 to 1952. Menzies was later High Commissioner to Burma and the Malay States from 1958 to 1963, High Commissioner to Australia from 1965 to 1972, and Representative to the North Atlantic Council from 1972 to 1976 before receiving his posting as Ambassador to China in 1976, serving concurrently as ambassador to Vietnam from 1976 to 1979, serving through the purge of the “Gang of Four” after the death of Chairman Mao and the rise of Deng Xiaoping to power. After leaving China, Menzies was Canada’s first Ambassador-at-Large for Disarmament before his retirement in 1982.

Maj. Michel Gauvin CVO OC DSO (1919-2003), 1980-1984. Michel Gauvin was born in Quebec City and attended the Université de Laval before serving as an officer in the Army during WWII. He joined the Department of External Affairs after the war and earned a degree from Carleton University while serving as an assistant in the Prime Ministers’ Office from 1946 to 1950. He served in postings abroad through the 1950s and early 1960s, including on special missions to the Congo during the Stanleyville Crisis in 1964 and to the Dominican Republic during its 1965 civil war. Gauvin was appointed Ambassador to Ethiopia from 1966 to 1969, Ambassador to Portugal from 1969 to 1970, and Ambassador to Greece from 1970 to 1975, then served as Consul-General in Strasbourg from 1976 to 1978 and Ambassador to Morocco from 1978 to 1980. After the end of his tenure as Ambassador to China, Gauvin retired from public service. He was awarded the French Légion d’honneur in 1995.

Richard Vessot Gorham ONB (1927-2011), 1984-1987. Born at Gorham’s Bluff, N.B., Richard Gorham served for a stint in the merchant marine at the end of WWII before studying at the University of New Brunswick and Clark University in Worcester, Mass., before joining the foreign service in 1952. He spent most of his career on postings in East Asia, including as Canadian commissioner to the International Commission for Supervision and Control in Cambodia from 1968 to 1970, before becoming Ambassador to China in 1984. After his tenure in Beijing, Gorham served as Ambassador to the Organization of American States from 1987 to 1990.

Earl Gordon Drake (1928-), 1987-1990. Earl Drake studied at the University of Saskatechewan and the University of Toronto, then worked as an archivist for the government of Saskatchewan before joining the foreign service in 1955. He served as Ambassador to Indonesia from 1982 to 1983 before becoming Ambasssador to China in 1987, where he served during the Tianamen Square protests and the retirement of Deng Xiaoping in favour of Jiang Zemin. After coming home from Beijing, Drake became a professor at Simon Fraser University from 1991 to 2006 and was president of the Canada-China Business Council from 2000 to 2001. He is now an Honorary Professor at the Institute of Asian Research at the University of British Columbia.

M. Fred Bild (1936-), 1990-1994. Fred Bild was born in Leipzig, Germany, the son of a Jewish furrier. His family fled to Belgium shortly before the start of WWII. As a child, he was put into hiding in a farm in the Belgian countryside to escape the Holocaust (his father was caught by the Germans and killed at Auschwitz). After WWII, he returned to his mother in Brussels, where she remarried; in 1948, the family immigrated to Montreal His mother sent him to a summer camp in the Laurentians, where he learned English from a young William Shatner, who was a camp counsellor there. Bild went to Concordia University in Montreal, where he married his childhood sweetheart Eva; the couple then went to London to pursue graduate work. Bild studied at UCL, then joined the foreign service in 1961. He was Ambassador to Thailand, Vietnam, Laos and Burma from 1979 to 1983 before ending out his diplomatic career as Ambassador to China from 1990 to 1994 and concurrently Ambassador to Mongolia from 1992 to 1994, afterwards becoming a professor at the Université de Montreal.

John Lawrence Paynter (1940-1995), 1994-1995. Born in Vancouver, John Paynter served in the Naval Reserve while studying at UBC from 1959 to 1963, then went on to graduate studies at Tufts and Oxford. Paynter was Ambassador to Thailand, Vietnam and Laos from 1983 to 1987, then High Commissioner to India from 1991 to 1994. Paynter died in Vancouver on 31 October 1995, 10 months into his tenure as Ambassador to China; he had left Beijing for Canada in May to undergo cancer treatment.

Kenneth Sunquist (acting) (Chargé d’affaires) October 1995-February 1996

Howard Balloch (1951-), 1996-2001. Howard Balloch was born in England while his father was attending a training assignment in paper-mill management, but the family returned home to Corner Brook, Nfld., before Howard was one. Balloch attended McGill, U of T, and the Fondation Nationale des Sciences Politiques in Paris. He joined the Department of External Affairs upon his return from Paris in 1976 and was posted to Jakarta from 1976 to 1979 (where he met his wife, Liani) and to Prague from 1984 to 1986 before taking up a post at External Affairs headquarters in Ottawa, serving as Assistant Deputy Minister for Asia and Representative to APEC from 1991 to 1994, then as Deputy Secretary to the Cabinet for National Unity in the Privy Council Office from 1994 to 1996 before becoming Ambassador to China. In 2001, Balloch concurrently became Canada’s first Ambassador to North Korea. After retiring from public service, Balloch founded a firm of investment advisors and merchant bankers in Beijing, running it until 2011. He is now a director of PacBridge Partners, an investment group in Hong Kong.

Joseph Caron (1947-), 2001-2005. Caron attended the University of Ottawa and joined the Trade Commissioner Service in 1972, serving in Saigon and Ankara before a long assignment in Tokyo. He spent most of the 1980s in private-sector dealings in the Far East, before working in Ottawa for the Department of Foreign Affairs in the 1990s. Caron was Ambassador to China from 2001 to 2005, coinciding with the retirement of Jiang Zemin and the elevation of Hu Jintao as leader of China. After serving as Ambassador to China, he was Ambassador to Japan from 2005 to 2008 and High Commissioner to India from 2008 to 2010 before leaving the diplomatic service and joining the board of directors of Manulife Financial. The Japanese government awarded him the Order of the Rising Sun, Gold and Silver Star, in 2017.

Robert G. Wright (1947-), 2005-2009. Born in Montreal, Robert Wright went to McGill and joined the civil service in 1971; he served in various diplomatic and economic posts until his appointment as Deputy Minister of International Trade in 1995, then as Ambassador to Japan from 2001 to 2005 before serving as Ambassador to China. He retired in 2009 and is now a Senior Fellow at the China Institute of the University of Alberta. His brothers, James Wright and David Wright, were also high-ranking Canadian diplomats.

David Mulroney, 2009-2012. David Mulroney was born in Halifax, attended St. Michael’s College at the University of Toronto, and joined the foreign service in 1981. From 1998 to 2001, he was Executive Director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei, then was Representative to APEC from 2001 to 2005. Mulroney then served as Foreign and Defence Policy Advisor to the Prime Minister from 2006 to 2007 and as Associate Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs for inter-departmental co-ordination of the mission in Afghanistan from 2007 to 2009 before his appointment as Ambassador to China. After retiring from the public service in 2012, he sat as President and Vice-Chancellor of St. Michael’s College from 2015 to 2018. He is now a Distinguished Fellow at the University of Toronto’s Munk School of Global Affairs and Public Policy. Pope Francis made Mulroney a Knight Commander of the Order of St. Gregory the Great in 2019.

Guy Saint-Jacques, 2012-2016. Guy Saint-Jacques attended the U de Montreal and joined the foreign service in 1977, serving around the world until being appointed as Ambassador-at-Large for Climate Change from 2010 to 2012, then as Ambassador to China from 2012 to 2016. He was Ambassador during the retirement of Hu Jintao and the rise of Xi Jinping as leader of China. Saint-Jacques retired in 2016.

Cindy Termorshuizen (acting) (Deputy Head of Mission) October 2016-March 2017

The Hon. Dr. John McCallum PC (1950-), 2017-2019. John McCallum was born in Montreal and attended private high schools before studying at Cambridge and the Université de Paris before earning a PhD in economics from McGill. He taught economics at various universities across Canada starting in 1976, culminating in his tenure as the Dean of Arts at McGill from 1992 to 1994. He left the school for a job as Chief Economist to the Royal Bank of Canada for six years, then was elected to Parliament as the Liberal MP for Markham in 2000, going on to be re-elected five more times. He served in the cabinets for three prime ministers: as Minister of National Defence (2002-2003) under Jean Chrétien, Minister of Veterans Affairs (2003-2004) and Minister of National Revenue (2004-2006) under Paul Martin, and Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship (2015-2017) under Justin Trudeau. McCallum resigned from Parliament in 2017 to accept the post of Ambassador to China. McCallum’s tenure in Beijing coincided with two major international incidents: the arrest of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou in Canada and the subsequent court case fighting her extradition to the US on charges of bank and wire fraud, and the arrest of Canadian nationals Michael Spavor and Michael Kovrig in China on charges of espionage. In January 2019, McCallum abruptly resigned as Ambassador at the request of Prime Minister Trudeau, giving no public reason.

Jim Nickel (acting) (Chargé d’affaires) January-September 2019

Dominic Barton (1962-), 2019-2021. Dominic Barton was born in Uganda; his father was an Anglican missionary, and his mother was a nurse. His family moved to Canada in 1969, settling near Chilliwack, B.C. Barton went to UBC, then studied at Oxford on a Rhodes Scholarship. After graduating, he briefly worked as a currency analyst for the Rothschilds in London before being hired by the Toronto office of the management-consultantcy firm of McKinsey & Company in 1986, where he would stay for 32 years, serving as chairman of its Asian operations in Shanghai from 2004 to 2009, then as the company’s Managing Director between 2009 and 2018. He then served as the chairman of mining conglomerate Teck from 2018 to 2019 before being appointed Ambassador to China – Canada’s first Ambassador to China with no prior diplomatic experience. In December 2021, Barton announced his imminent departure from the role of Ambassador; in May 2022, when he became chairman of mining conglomerate Rio Tinto.

Jim Nickel (acting) (Chargé d’affaires) (2nd time) December 2021-September 2022

Jennifer May, 2022-now. May was born in Toronto and studied political science and German at Université de Laval, then, after a year studying international affairs at the University of Vienna, she joined the Department of External Affairs in 1990. After serving as Second Secretary for social affairs to the Canadian embassy to Germany in Bonn from 1991 to 1994, she returned to Ottawa to serve as a Senior Desk Officer in the Eastern Europe Division for political analysis of the former Yugoslavia. After taking two years off to learn Mandarin Chinese, May served as Vice-Consul to Hong Kong and Macau from 1998 to 2000, then First Secretary of the Political Division at the Beijing embassy from 2000 to 2004. After a 2-year stint in Ottawa in the Northern Europe Relations Division, May served as a Counsellor for Political, Economic and Public Affairs at the embassies in Vienna from 2006 to 2010 and Bangkok from 2010 to 2012. May returned to desk jobs in Ottawa for 3 years before serving as Deputy Head of Mission at the German embassy from 2015 to 2019, when she was appointed as Ambassador to Brazil, where she served until July 2022, two months before May was appointed as Ambassador to China.

Canada’s Consuls-General to Hong Kong and Macao have been:

Colin Russell, 1997-2001.

Anthony Burger, 2001-2004.

Gerald K. Campbell, 2004-2008.

Doreen Steidle, 2008-2011.

J. Ian Burchett, 2011-2016.

Jeff Nankivell, 2016-2021.
